I agree with poster that countries do not have relations. Only people have relations. Countries have interests. US and China interests align in certain areas like making the world economy grow so everyone can get rich. In other areas, like controlling the world's oil supply, they are at odds.

I think the best strategy for the US is to enlist China as the junior hegemon. Give China more responsibility. For example, a nuclear and psychotic North Korea is really a Chinese problem far more than an American problem. Perhaps US should simply withdraw from Korea altogether -- it is far away and very expensive. The Chinese are more than powerful enough to support a major trading partner (south korea) against north korean lunatics. Giving China that responsibility would possibly help bind them to the loose aggregation of reasonable countries.

I think the currency thing should be handled by other western governments who have exactly the same interest as the US in letting the Chinese currency rise against the dollar. Think that it would be far easier to make happen if big hegemon US wasn't pushing so hard. Wasn't making it so that for China to do the reasonable thing (in their long-term interests, as well as everyone else'
s) wouldn't seem like a defeat for them.

Is this an April Fools Day joke? When does the madness end? 2.4 million American jobs lost since 2001 because of the mercantilist economic policies of China's leaders.

Step 1: Let's be honest with ourselves (and China and the rest of the world) and name China a currency manipulator

Step 2: Enforce our trade laws and apply countervailing duties to offset the currency advantage that makes Chinese imports 40% cheaper ON TOP of the subsidization, cheap labor, lack of environmental regulations, export rebates, and other illegal tactics

We're in the middle of a trade war and our leaders are asleep at the wheel. The clock is ticking on American workers. When will the alarm go off in the Oval Office?

The Obama administration's appeasement of Chinese sensibilities is just more proof that your government (be it Bushesque or Obamistic) is owned lock, stock, and barrel by WalMart, Wall Street, and the Chinese lobby.

The sad part is that it would be so easy to put America back on the right track.

The "Import Certificates" scheme proposed by Warren Buffett, and endorsed by Ralph Gomory, is the only hope the United States has of skewering the politically-correct holy cow of "free trade" (known to non-idiots as Chinese mercantilism), restoring balance to America's foreign trade, and putting millions of Americans back to work. It would force balanced trade, something the geniuses who call themselves "economists" can't quite grasp the necessity of.

Too bad the chance of these vital changes being implemented in this decade is zero. It would be so much less traumatic if the United States could simply make them without first having to endure a catastrophic economic collapse, Treasury default, and full-blown depression. In the words of Winston Churchill, America will do the right thing after exhausting all the alternatives.

Further, tighting our relation with China is driven by our Merchant Marine Industrial Complex (MMIC) who would be our ambassadors in the Orient. However, long-term trade policies with China is the mechanism to surrender fears between our nations whereby building trust and honor. Historically, trade has broke down cultural barriers between two given countries. It is time to breakdown cultural barriers with the Chinese.

Antonio Ivan Easterling
Chief Editor
The Proletarian Review

The doctors cite the argument that Marijuana causes psychosis, but this has never been shown in a clinical study.  Rather, there have been observational studies that show that people with psychoses use marijuana is disproportionate numbers.  This is no way shows a causal relationship.  On the contrary, it is very likely that such individuals, like people with Tourette's, self-medicate with marijuana because they find that it eases their condition.  The doctors should be more careful with their advice, and more skeptical of observational studies, which have been shown to be wrong again and again.  Only rigorously applied double-blind clinical studies will answer questions like these.

I won't be buying an iPad anytime soon. It's a device designed too much for "consumption" rather than "production." The media and entertainment worlds already have enough space in my daily routine. They don't need another portal into my life. Sure, it would be nice to have one for around the house, when I'm too lazy to open my laptop. But the cost does not justify this.
Would it be user-friendly  to my 83 year old Mom who was computer savvy but says she doesn't want to use them any longer? Or - would it be a waste of money for her?

Years ago, people like my grandparents, parents and myself only went into debt to buy things of real substance like their homes and cars. We had the silly notion that if you could not afford something, you didn't buy it. Most young people today don't seem to mind being thousands of dollars in debt to buy shoes, sports tickets or vacations. No one seems the least bit ashamed by being in debt, not the government or the average Joe. We were told in the 1980's that deficits don't matter, if the government doesn't care why should anyone else. The Bush administration balanced budgets by lowering taxes for the rich and borrowing from China to pay for everything. I keep wondering why no one complained about this during the Bush years.

Just like the general public, the government should cut up its credit cards and make sure everyone pays their fair share in taxes, stop paying for wars we cannot afford, stop policing the world, bring all the troops home from places we haven't fought in 50 years and only pay foreign aid to the neediest countries. Maybe then someday the government will have a surplus again, but only if we stay focused and use a great deal of common sense.

Want to save money and keep from adding to the deficit? Keep the GOP away from the "lock box". They ballooned the deficit with overseas adventures, electronic border walls that do not work, tax cuts for their cronies, etc. The Democrats in the 90's morphed into the party of responsibility while the Republicans masqueraded as one in the last decade. We do need to work on fiscal restraint, but I am afraid that we will see all progress eroded if the party of "no" decides to "party" like it's 2003 again...

I fail to see why Dr. Krugman presents the issue of financial reform as a choice between breaking up the big financial institutions or simply regulating them.  Each approach has merit, and there is no reason why we could not implement both, along with an independent consumer protection agency.  Redundant safety mechanisms are the hallmark of well-designed systems.  In order to avoid injury in automobile accidents we have seat belts, airbags, collapsible steering columns, shock absorbing bumpers, non-shattering windscreens, a collapsible body, and an engine that goes under the passenger compartment upon impact.  Since the banks can potentially destroy the global economy, we need to have multiple safety systems in place.

Most Americans understand that America is richer for the immigrants that have come to our shores.  What is wrong with the picture is many of the those coming here are not assimilating.  That was the promise. Come!  But come in the front door!  Apply for citizenship. Don't sneak in and live in the shadows. Learn our language.  Pay taxes just as every American does to support our country. Get an education without taking advantage of the system.  I am of German and Welsh descent, but I AM AN AMERICAN!!!  Until an immigrant can follow the rules and assimilate as an American, they are missing the point of America.  Flouting the rules of immigration, taking advantage of the goodness of this country and refusing to "become" American is a slap in the face to all those that HAVE played by the rules.  Anyone coming here can remain proud of their heritage, but  to come here and truly be part of the promise of this country, they must make their first allegiance to AMERICA!...land of the free and home of the brave.   Become one of us the RIGHT way.

Ed, #13, asks, "Did you ever wonder about why most exempt folks are consistently asked to work 45, 50, or 60 hours per week? "

One reason is that the employer saves by not hiring more workers, for whom he would have to provide at least token health insurance. The new health bill locks this in place forever. In contrast, single-payer - taking the employer out of the process - could have allowed a huge number of unemployed to move into a system where the average work week is 30 or 32 hours.
